position.marginalia_text: Nullus perfectus, aut excellens habitus sine quotidiana Exercitatione.

marginalia.translation: No habit is perfect or excellent without daily exercise.

position.marginalia_text: ( Puer est, qui nondùm didicit viuere.)

marginalia.translation: A boy is he who has not yet learned to live.

position.marginalia_text: ( Stultus est, qui non sapit sine libris.)

marginalia.translation: A fool is he who has no sense without books.

position.marginalia_text: Vnus, plus quàm mille. Continua articulorum, ) sensuumq[ue] agitatio, diuina Eudoxi philosophia. Sudat nobilissima Industria: nec cessat unq[uam].

marginalia.translation: One rather than a thousand. The continual exercise of the joints and senses: this is the divine philosophy of Eudoxus. The most renowned industriousness swears and it never stops.

position.marginalia_text: Bona corporis, animi, fortuna[e] quotidiè augenda viro serio: alitèr Nugatori.

marginalia.translation: The goods of the body, mind, and fortune must be increased daily by the earnest man; otherwise, they belong to a mere braggart.

position.marginalia_text: Cum Fortuna, et foeminis impetuosè: cum Virtute, et Viris respectiuè. Foemina[e], omnium horarum homines: nunq[uam] imparata[e].

marginalia.translation: Witih Fortune and impetuous women; with Virtue and respectful men. Women, men for all seasons: never prepared.

position.marginalia_text: { Philosophus non est, qui non est polytechnus, polyda[e]dalus, polymechanus, polytropus, polychrestus; et omninò panergus.

marginalia.translation: He who is not polytechnus, polydaedalus, polymechanus, polytropus, polychrestus, and entirely panergus is not a philosopher.

position.marginalia_text: Fortunam habet ad manum, qui Seipsum habet ad unguem; id est, corpus, et animu[m] suu[m].

marginalia.translation: He who knows himself by heart (that is, he who knows his body and mind) keeps fortune at hand.
